comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Neptune ironworks last big ship was the Lara completed for the Waterford Steamship Company in 1868, and with her sleek lines and powerful engines (200 HP), she reduced the passage time Liverpool to Waterford route from 30 hours to just over 18 hours. When launched she was one of the largest cattle boats afloat and gave her owners 40 years of consistent and fairly uneventful service before her sale for breaking up in 1908. From: snap.waterfordcoco.ie/collections/ejournals/123308/123308...

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Now theres a photograph to warm the cockles of the heart and theres a name to warm many a temper.  Peter "The Packer" O'Brien no less a notorious packer of juries who turned on his own and became a Unionist of the most vivid orange kind.  When I was growing up the name Peter the Packer was still reviled and derided.  He would need a troop of cavalry and mounted police to keep him safe especially in Munster.  Well done Carol, you chose wisely and well though probably the wrong date!

comment.author: 53227388@N00
comment._content: The SS Lara also appears in the NLI catalogue here: catalogue.nli.ie/Record/P_WP_1847 It seems to have been on a regular Waterford-Liverpool run: From the personal memories of Edward Phelan, former director general of the International Labour Organisation (1888- 1967): "All through the week there would be other steamers to watch, the Lara, the Comeragh or the Dunbrody on their regular service to Liverpool, Clyde Shipping Company’s steamers bound for Glasgow; and, once in a while, some strange tramp, rusty and ill-kempt would appear, or a small schooner would make her way up the river under sail helped by the tide. www.ilo.org/public/english/century/information_resources/... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_J._Phelan

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: The article in the Irish Times from Friday, 12 March 1897 talks of the Lord Chief Justice, Sir Peter O'Brien, Bart., opening the Commission for the Assizes in the City Court yesterday, i.e. Thursday, 11 March 1897. So I've just cherry picked from a longish article to give you a flavour of what was going on: "... Nicholas Murphy, John O'Neill, Bryan Cunningham, senior, Patrick Henneberry, and Paul Caulfield, junior, were indicted for riotous and unlawful assembly. ... Mr. Ryan [Q.C., Prosecutor for the Crown] reviewed the history of the dispute in the bacon trade, and said the pig buyers got it into their heads that they had a sort of vested right to sell direct to the merchants, even though the farmers and others might think it better for their interests that they should not do so. Out of this dispute the unfortunate riots - the savage riots - which they were about to investigate, had arisen. On the 22nd of January the riots reached a culminating point, if they had not done so before, and the result was that whether terrorised or not, the men of Richardson's were afraid to act in the employment, and the merchants were obliged to import strangers to work the Yarra Yarra. They were attacked by a mob of the most violent description, and the police who were protecting them were obstructed and assaulted. He asked the jury, having heard the evidence, to find a verdict of guilty by doing which they would be asserting the law and assisting in putting down violence and outrage. Acting Sergeant Tobin, Cahir, examined by Mr. Cherry [Q.C, Prosecutor for the Crown], described the attack upon the workers at the Yarra Yarra. He saw Henneberry strike one of the men with a stick, and there there was an attack made upon the police. They were struck again and again, and the police were obliged to draw their batons and repel the onslaught. He saw Bryan Cunningham strik a man named Kavanagh several times with a stick and he pursued him. Paul Caulfield said, "Don't mind that man", and made a stroke at witness. In the melee he got a terrible blow on the nose which broke it. Cross-examined by Mr. Redmond [Defence, and an M.P.] - I presume you are very familiar with the appearance of the city? No; there were two or three hundred people in the crowd, and all I am able to identify are the defendants. The jury found Henneberry and O'Neill guilty. Sentence deferred. ..."
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: James Cunningham and his brothers of Waterford were pig dealers in 1901. www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1901/Waterford/Water... This is his family in 1911. www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Waterford/Water... "February 23, 1917" www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/6922921683

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] The Malcomson family was an Irish Quaker family active in various businesses during the 19th century. www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1901/Waterford/Portl... The family operated ship building in Waterford and established the 'Neptune Ironworks'. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malcomson_family The NLI has some photos of the Misses Malcomson. catalogue.nli.ie/Record/P_WP_1069

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: If anyone is interested in the history of shipbuilding in Waterford I would highly reccommend Bill Irish's book, Shipbuilding in Waterford, 1820-1882: A Historical, Technical and Pictorial Study. Amazon.Com Waterfords Shipyards

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: More pig riot news. Freeman's March 2nd THE BACON TRADE DISPUTE RELEASE OF PRISONERS AT WATERFORD Waterford, Monday The bacon trade dispute continues unrelentful. To-day Messrd Cunningham, Fitzgerald and Ryan, who were sentenced to three months imprisonment at the Winter Assizes for assaulting bacon merchants, were released. They were met by a number of friends, and yielding to the wishes of the Pigbuyers Association no demonstration took place, and absolute tranquility prevailed. The three men looked well and in good spirits, except Fitzgerald, who could not suppress his grief at entering his home, which was made terribly desolate by the death, during his imprisonment, of his wife, mother of eight children. Waterford, Monday night Late to-night there was an imposing popular demonstration in celebration of the release of the prisoners. The large multitude was accompanied by a band and fifty torchbearers.
